Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VYG-D431-DXVP-V54V-00000-00Questions for Chase (away) Bank2019-04-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:20:02ZLexisNexisEDITORIALPg. 4Questions for Chase (away) BankMichelle Malkin

I have been a Chase Bank customer for years. Who knows how much longer it'll be? Will the company's thought police come for me next? How about you? If you are a non-leftist who does business with the financial giant owned by J.R Morgan Chase & Co., you need to ask questions and get answers.

On Tuesday, investigative journalist James O'Keefe and his Project Veritas team released a disturbing new video on the runaround that Chase officials gave Texas conservative entrepreneur Enrique Tarrio about his canceled account. Big business may very well be enabling America's very own version of the Chinese social credit system in which political dissent is flagged, shunned, punished and eradicated.

First, some background:

Tarrio is a young, peaceful, Afro-Cuban freethinker and chairman of the Proud Boys organization. In February 2019, the Texas Trump supporter received a letter from Chase Bank informing him that "after careful consideration," the financial institution could "no longer support" his banking account. The notice followed a hit piece against minorities who support the president by The Daily Beast, a reliable echo chamber for the discredited Southern Poverty Law Center smear machine.

Tarrio was subsequently kicked off Chase's payment processor, which he used to sell patriotic and pro-Trump T-shirts. Next, he was deplatformed from Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Airbnb, FirstData, Square, Stripe and PayPal before losing his bank accounts. When I asked on Twitter in February why we can't have just one financial institution that doesn't cave to social justice warriors, the official ChaseTwitter account tweeted me back:

"Hi Michelle, this article is inaccurate. We did not close his personal account. We do not close accounts based on political affiliation."

I pointed out that Chase's letter clearly stated that the company had closed his account. "So if not for political reasons," I asked, "why, 'after careful consideration,' did you close his account?" The social media manager of Chase's corporate Twitter account, previously so eager to spill the tea, replied: "For privacy reasons, we can't say more."

Thanks to Project Veritas, we now know more. Undercover audio and video exposed how:

- One Chase employee blamed

"clerical" issues on Tarrio's account cancellation. - Another stated: "I see nothing that indicates any reason why the account should be closed. I don't see any outstanding transactions or anything ridiculous." Another explained: "Chase is not involved with any like, you know, alt-right people or anything." Those with "no moral character" are people that "the bank usually doesn't get involved with in any "business relationships, period."

-Several repeated a company line in Tarrio's mysterious file: "Decision is not reversible."

Others who received Chase shutdown notices so far in 2019: conservative Rebel Media contributor Martina Markota, anti-sharia and pro-borders investigative journalist Laura Loomer and U.S. Army combat vet and vocal Trump supporter Joe Biggs. Were Mar-kota's, Loomer's and Biggs' removals "clerical" errors or unfounded or were they based on an ideological litmus test disguised as a "moral character" assessment? More questions arise: How exactly is J.R Morgan Chase's $500,000 donation last year to the SPLC left-wing operatives being put to use?

Why did the company embrace a known defamation racket whose stated mission is to "destroy" its political enemies on the right?

What comment does Chase have now that SPLC's top leaders have been purged amid internal accusations of intolerance and discrimination within the walls of the notorious Poverty Palace?

Does Chase keep tabs on high-profile conservative customers' political speech on social media platforms? Is Chase operating from the same playbook as Paypal, which is booting off conservatives in consultation with the SPLC? One of its most recent victims: Luke Rohlfing, a young reporter for BigLeaguePolitics.com, who had exposed how the payment processor was allowing Open Borders Inc. heavyweight Pueblo Sin Fronteras to raise money for illegal immigrant caravans conspiring to break our immigration laws - even though Paypal's own terms of service state clearly that users may not engage in any activities that "violate any law, statute, ordinance or regulation."

Tarrio warns of the speech-squelching pattern emerging across Silicon Valley and on Wall Street: "First we get silenced on social media, then Paypal, then I get debanked. It's a very dangerous trend."

He is not alone. Former Toronto mayoral candidate and social media commentator Faith Goldy told me: "To date I've been banned from: PayPal, Patreon, GoFundMe, Airbnb, Face-book and Instagram. I've committed no crime! My only fault is loving my country and quoting government statistics to a camera from my kitchen table. The nature of big tech censorship is imperialistic and these Silicon Valley nerds won't stop until every freethinker is snuffed or scared into submission."

As for Chase Bank, I sent all my questions to chief communications officer Patricia Wexler, who challenged the authenticity of one of the employees recorded by Veritas (O'Keefe showed proof of the Chase New York media relations number dialed and had audio of the employee identifying himself as a Chase rep) and ignored the substance of the report.

Evasion and denial are surefire ways to lose business. Is it Chase Bank or Chase (SET ITAL)Away(END ITAL) Bank? Inquiring customers would like to know.

Michelle Malkin's email address is writemalkin@gmail.com

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VX2-XF31-JC8H-N0M3-00000-00Questions for Chase (Away) Bank2019-04-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:20:03ZLexisNexisQUESTIONS FOR CHASE (AWAY) BANKQuestions for Chase (Away) BankMichelle Malkin

I have been a Chase Bank customer for years. Who knows how much longer it'll be? Will the company's thought police come for me next? How about you? If you are a non-leftist who does business with the financial giant owned by J.P. Morgan Chase & Co., you need to ask questions and get answers.

On Tuesday, investigative journalist James O'Keefe and his Project Veritas team released a disturbing new video on the runaround that Chase officials gave Texas conservative entrepreneur Enrique Tarrio about his canceled account. Big business may very well be enabling America's very own version of the Chinese social credit system in which political dissent is flagged, shunned, punished and eradicated.

First, some background:

Tarrio is a young, peaceful, Afro-Cuban freethinker and chairman of the Proud Boys organization. In February 2019, the Texas Trump supporter received a letter from Chase Bank informing him that "after careful consideration," the financial institution could "no longer support" his banking account. The notice followed a hit piece against minorities who support the president by The Daily Beast, a reliable echo chamber for the discredited Southern Poverty Law Center smear machine.

Tarrio was subsequently kicked off Chase's payment processor, which he used to sell patriotic and pro-Trump T-shirts. Next, he was deplatformed from Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Airbnb, FirstData, Square, Stripe and PayPal before losing his bank accounts. When I asked on Twitter in February why we can't have just one financial institution that doesn't cave to social justice warriors, the official ChaseTwitter account tweeted me back:

"Hi Michelle, this article is inaccurate. We did not close his personal account. We do not close accounts based on political affiliation."

I pointed out that Chase's letter clearly stated that the company had closed his account. "So if not for political reasons," I asked, "why, 'after careful consideration,' did you close his account?" The social media manager of Chase's corporate Twitter account, previously so eager to spill the tea, replied: "For privacy reasons, we can't say more."

Thanks to Project Veritas, we now know more. Undercover audio and video exposed how:

One Chase employee blamed "clerical" issues on Tarrio's account cancellation.

Another stated: "I see nothing that indicates any reason why the account should be closed. I don't see any outstanding transactions or anything ridiculous."

Another explained: "Chase is not involved with any like, you know, alt-right people or anything." Those with "no moral character" are people that "the bank usually doesn't get involved with in any "business relationships, period."

Several repeated a company line in Tarrio's mysterious file: "Decision is not reversible."

Others who received Chase shutdown notices so far in 2019: conservative Rebel Media contributor Martina Markota, anti-sharia and pro-borders investigative journalist Laura Loomer and U.S. Army combat vet and vocal Trump supporter Joe Biggs. Were Markota's, Loomer's and Biggs' removals "clerical" errors or unfounded or were they based on an ideological litmus test disguised as a "moral character" assessment?

More questions arise:

How exactly is J.P. Morgan Chase's $500,000 donation last year to the SPLC left-wing operatives being put to use?

Why did the company embrace a known defamation racket whose stated mission is to "destroy" its political enemies on the right?

What comment does Chase have now that SPLC's top leaders have been purged amid internal accusations of intolerance and discrimination within the walls of the notorious Poverty Palace?

Does Chase keep tabs on high-profile conservative customers' political speech on social media platforms?

Is Chase operating from the same playbook as Paypal, which is booting off conservatives in consultation with the SPLC? One of its most recent victims: Luke Rohlfing, a young reporter for BigLeaguePolitics.com, who had exposed how the payment processor was allowing Open Borders Inc. heavyweight Pueblo Sin Fronteras to raise money for illegal immigrant caravans conspiring to break our immigration laws even though Paypal's own terms of service state clearly that users may not engage in any activities that "violate any law, statute, ordinance or regulation."

Tarrio warns of the speech-squelching pattern emerging across Silicon Valley and on Wall Street: "First we get silenced on social media, then Paypal, then I get debanked. It's a very dangerous trend."

He is not alone. Former Toronto mayoral candidate and social media commentator Faith Goldy told me: "To date I've been banned from: PayPal, Patreon, GoFundMe, Airbnb, Facebook and Instagram. I've committed no crime! My only fault is loving my country and quoting government statistics to a camera from my kitchen table. The nature of big tech censorship is imperialistic and these Silicon Valley nerds won't stop until every freethinker is snuffed or scared into submission."

As for Chase Bank, I sent all my questions to chief communications officer Patricia Wexler, who challenged the authenticity of one of the employees recorded by Veritas (O'Keefe showed proof of the Chase New York media relations number dialed and had audio of the employee identifying himself as a Chase rep) and ignored the substance of the report.

Evasion and denial are surefire ways to lose business. Is it Chase Bank or Chase Away Bank? Inquiring customers would like to know.

Michelle Malkin's email address is writemalkin@gmail.com To find out more about Michelle Malkin and read features by other Creators Syndicate writers and cartoonists, visit the Creators Syndicate website at www.creators.com.

How about you?

If you are a nonleftist who does business with the financial giant owned by J.P. Morgan Chase & Co., you need to ask questions and get answers.

On Tuesday, investigative journalist James O'Keefe and his Project Veritas team released a disturbing new video on the runaround that Chase officials gave Texas conservative entrepreneur Enrique Tarrio about his canceled account. Big business may very well be enabling America's very own version of the Chinese social credit system in which political dissent is flagged, shunned, punished and eradicated.

First, some background: Tarrio is a young, peaceful, Afro-Cuban freethinker and chairman of the Proud Boys organization. In February 2019, the Texas Trump supporter received a letter from Chase Bank informing him that "after careful consideration," the financial institution could "no longer support" his banking account. The notice followed a hit piece against minorities who support the president by The Daily Beast, a reliable echo chamber for the discredited Southern Poverty Law Center smear machine.

Tarrio was subsequently kicked off Chase's payment processor, which he used to sell patriotic and pro-Trump T-shirts. Next, he was deplatformed from Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Airbnb, FirstData, Square, Stripe and PayPal before losing his bank accounts. When I asked on Twitter in February why we can't have just one financial institution that doesn't cave to social justice warriors, the official ChaseTwitter account tweeted me back: "Hi Michelle, this article is inaccurate. We did not close his personal account. We do not close accounts based on political affiliation." I pointed out that Chase's letter clearly stated that the company had closed his account.

"So if not for political reasons," I asked, "why, 'after careful consideration,' did you close his account?" The social media manager of Chase's corporate Twitter account, previously so eager to spill the tea, replied: "For privacy reasons, we can't say more." Thanks to Project Veritas, we now know more. Undercover audio and video exposed how:

· One Chase employee blamed "clerical" issues on Tarrio's account cancellation.

· Another stated: "I see nothing that indicates any reason why the account should be closed. I don't see any outstanding transactions or anything ridiculous."

· Another explained: "Chase is not involved with any like, you know, alt-right people or anything." Those with "no moral character" are people that "the bank usually doesn't get involved with in any "business relationships, period."

· Several repeated a company line in Tarrio's mysterious file: "Decision is not reversible." Others who received Chase shutdown notices so far in 2019: conservative Rebel Media contributor Martina Markota, anti-sharia and pro-borders investigative journalist Laura Loomer and U.S. Army combat vet and vocal Trump supporter Joe Biggs. Were Markota's, Loomer's and Biggs' removals "clerical" errors or unfounded or were they based on an ideological litmus test disguised as a "moral character" assessment?

More questions arise: How exactly is J.P. Morgan Chase's $500,000 donation last year to the SPLC leftwing operatives being put to use?

Why did the company embrace a known defamation racket whose stated mission is to "destroy" its political enemies on the right?

What comment does Chase have now that SPLC's top leaders have been purged amid internal accusations of intolerance and discrimination within the walls of the notorious Poverty Palace?

Does Chase keep tabs on high-profile conservative customers' political speech on social media platforms?

Is Chase operating from the same playbook as Paypal, which is booting off conservatives in consultation with the SPLC?

One of its most recent victims: Luke Rohlfing, a young reporter for BigLeague-Politics.com, who had exposed how the payment processor was allowing Open Borders Inc. heavyweight Pueblo Sin Fronteras to raise money for illegal immigrant caravans conspiring to break our immigration laws - even though Paypal's own terms of service state clearly that users may not engage in any activities that "violate any law, statute, ordinance or regulation." Tarrio warns of the speech-squelching pattern emerging across Silicon Valley and on Wall Street: "First we get silenced on social media, then Paypal, then I get debanked. It's a very dangerous trend." He is not alone.

Former Toronto mayoral candidate and social media commentator Faith Goldy told me: "To date I've been banned from: PayPal, Patreon, GoFundMe, Airbnb, Facebook and Instagram.

I've committed no crime!

My only fault is loving my country and quoting government statistics to a camera from my kitchen table.

The nature of big tech censorship is imperialistic and these Silicon Valley nerds won't stop until every freethinker is snuffed or scared into submission." As for Chase Bank, I sent all my questions to chief communications officer Patricia Wexler, who challenged the authenticity of one of the employees recorded by Veritas (O'Keefe showed proof of the Chase New York media relations number dialed and had audio of the employee identifying himself as a Chase rep) and ignored the substance of the report.

Evasion and denial are surefire ways to lose business. Is it Chase Bank or Chase Away Bank?

Inquiring customers would like to know.

Michelle Malkin's email address is writemalkin@gmail.com

urn:contentItem:5XBD-CCB1-DXH2-61NN-00000-00Questions Over When 737 Max will Return to the Skies; Facebook Pledges $1 Billion to Help Ease Growing Affordable Housing Crisis in California; Lexus Unveils Electric Concept Car; UPS Touts Strong E-Commerce Growth Ahead of Holidays2019-10-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:20:02ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTDavid Abney, Omeed Malik, Art Hogan, Bill Baruch, Joseph DeNardi, Roger Williams, Ivan Feinseth, Dave RicksNEWSFinancial102302cb.231Questions Over When 737 Max will Return to the Skies; Facebook Pledges $1 Billion to Help Ease Growing Affordable Housing Crisis in California; Lexus Unveils Electric Concept Car; UPS Touts Strong E-Commerce Growth Ahead of HolidaysMaria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Cheryl Casone, Jackie DeAngelis

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back.

Good Wednesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. Happy Wednesday.

I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Wednesday, October 23rd.

Your top stories right now at 7:00 a.m. on the button on the East Coast.

Earnings in focus driving markets this morning. The morning under pressure after missing (INAUDIBLE) and revenue estimates, also cutting its full year guidance. Stock down four and three-quarters percent.

The Boeing 737 Max crisis and the company's bottom line coming up. The embattled aerospace giant Boeing reporting earnings in about 30 minutes. We will have those numbers and get you the full analysis as well.

Mark Zuckerberg is on the hot seat this morning. The Facebook CEO to defend his proposed cryptocurrency, testifying on Capitol Hill later today, ready to admit the social giant has trust issues. We'll take a look at what to expect as Facebook shares are down a fraction this morning.

Broader markets meanwhile look like this. Futures indicating a decline at the start of trading thanks to Caterpillar largely. Caterpillar will cut about 60 points off the Dow this morning. Yesterday's uncertainty and, of course, Brexit also an issue. But the Dow this morning down 89 points. The S&P was down 6 on top of yesterday's declines.

S&P was down 10 points yesterday at the close. The Dow was down 39 points. And the Nasdaq lower by 58. By the way, the S&P is still about 1 percent away from an all-time high.

Global markets this morning look like this. European indices are mixed. FT 100 is up 7 points as the Brexit drama continues. Parliament approving Prime Minister Boris Johnson's withdrawal agreement but not agreeing to his speedy timetable. Now it is up to the E.U. to allow an extension.

CAC 40 in Paris is down 37. The DAX index in Germany down 7 points.

There are growing concerns over Hong Kong putting pressure on markets in Asia overnight. Take a look. Nikkei in Japan able to finish with slight gains. But the others down as you see there. Hang Seng in Hong Kong down almost 1 percent.

All those stories coming up this Wednesday morning. And joining me to break it all down: Fox Business' Dagen McDowell; National Securities Corporation chief market strategist Art Hogan; and Farvahar Partners founder and CEO Omeed Malik.

Great to see everybody this morning.

ART HOGAN, CHIEF MARKET STRATEGIST, NATIONAL SECURITIES CORPORATION: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: We're waiting on a number of earnings which will likely impact markets but Caterpillar's the story of the day and so far stock is down on this earnings miss because I guess it is an indicator of the global economy.

HOGAN: Sure, it's an indicator of a part of the global economy that we've known has been slow for a while. For manufacturing, when you talk about what's going on in the world, yes we know there's a slowdown. Where is it getting hurt the most and it's manufacturing.

And whether we look at manufacturing because of Boeing not delivering the 737 Max or General Motors being in a 30-day strike or just the, you know, the slower activity that we're seeing in general.

Also remember Caterpillar is affected by what's going on in minerals and mining. All the commodity production that's going on globally and we know that has slowed too. So Caterpillar's the tip of the sword for what we see as global economic slowdown.

But to Dagen's point, a lot of this are priced in.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

HOGAN: I mean the S&P 500 is up about 20 percent, it's up 8 percent on year-to-date basis. So we're always -- I'm always surprised by how much we're surprised. But I'm also -- I'm still shocked that Cat didn't come out at some juncture and say hey listen, we've got to (INAUDIBLE) or at least take our guidance down so they wouldn't have this disappointment on earnings day.

BARTIROMO: Yes. It's off of the lows. The Morgan Stanley analysts this morning telling clients there's a slight earnings recession going on at Caterpillar.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: No, the quote from the CEO was our volumes declined as dealers reduced their inventories, and end-user demand while positive was lower than our expectations.

But overall, the earnings are way down from a year ago, down 13 and-a-half percent from a year ago. So not only is it a miss but it's a double-digit decline in earnings. And then also cutting its full year outlook and total sales and revenue off by 5.6 percent from a year ago. So it's red.

HOGAN: Right.

BARTIROMO: All right. We're watching that one.

Meanwhile, our top story this hour is keeping big tech in check. Facebook's CEO, Mark Zuckerberg, is going to be testifying on Capitol Hill later today in front of the House Financial Services Committee. He is expected to face questions on Facebook's cryptocurrency, Libra and whether the public can trust the embattled tech giant to handle users' finances.

In his opening statement, Zuckerberg argues if American technology companies do not take the lead on digital currencies other countries will.

Here's what he says. It reads in part -- this is the opening statement this morning -- "If healthy skepticism becomes all out hostility, we'll put a lot of progress at risk, not just in the world where American technology companies have an opportunity to champion American values. I think it would be bad for our country and the world if companies were discouraged from taking on challenges like these and settled for safer options that reinforce the status quo. That would harm our national reputation", he says, "for innovation, make our economy less competitive and end up concentrating more power in the hands of existing players rather than people."

We're going to talk about that, get your reaction to that.

HOGAN: Ok.

BARTIROMO: Joining us right now is Texas Congressman, Financial Services Committee member Roger Williams. Congressman -- it's good to see you this morning.

REP. ROGER WILLIAMS (R-TX): Good to see you.

BARTIROMO: What's your reaction to the opening statement?

WILLIAMS: Well, I'm anxious to hear what he has to say. You know, I mean I think America should lead the way in innovation and I'm all for that. I'm kind of an old school guy. I'm a Main Street business guy.

But I want to hear what he has to say. And let's assume too that the private sector can do things great. We know they can. So let's see -- let's see what he talks about and let's see where he thinks he can take this thing.

BARTIROMO: Well, how come it took them so long to admit that they were breaching our privacy and selling our information to advertisers? I mean can we trust them on cryptocurrency after what we've just been through in terms of privacy?

WILLIAMS: Well that's going to be something to ask him. I mean, you know, they didn't say anything until they had to say something. And this is important when you're talking about cryptocurrency. I'm still a dollar- bill guy.

And I want to know are the consumers going to be protected. How is it going to work for Main Street America? How is it going to work for a business like I have? I sit going to make things easier, harder or whatever? And can I trust them?

OMEED MALIK, FOUNDER & CEO, FARVAHAR PARTNERS: Hi, Congressman. This is Omeed Malik.

WILLIAMS: Hey -- Omeed.

MALIK: I would just say that if you think about why are they getting into this business -- that's the first question to ask. And that is so they can track the spending behavior of the American citizen. And he's going to use China as a boogeyman.

The difference is that the Chinese government is the one who is doing this, not a private corporation. So I certainly agree that you want innovation out of the private sector but to what end?

Look at all the different businesses they're in and all seems in order to track citizens. If they're going to get into a currency sector, they need to be regulated to the full extent just like a bank would in some cases. And so I hope to the extent that our congressmen are speaking about this, that we're going to actually have it be regulated because this is a company that has shown bad faith in the past and continues to expand in area after area and swallows up any innovation. And it's also a monopoly.

WILLIAMS: Yes. I mean I agree with what you're saying. That's what we're going to have to talk out about today and learn more about it. The transparency is going to have to be important -- to protect the consumer, it's going to have to be important. And I mean that's the bottom line, that's what we do here.

And as a small business person, I want to make sure that I'm protected. And those are the things he's going to have to answer.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I like that. That's a good question. Is it just to track everybody, to see what they're spending their money on?

MCDOWELL: Omeed -- I'm going to ask you a question. How many people with respect, Congressman -- how many people in Washington really understand how Facebook's business works? Because it's vast.

And again, when Mark Zuckerberg first appeared on Capitol Hill he was very, very prepared in terms of rehearsed by -- well-rehearsed by his legal team.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And he was very focused and very respectful. But I don't -- the questions didn't really get to the bottom of what Facebook has been up to literally for the last 12 years or so.

MALIK: Dagen -- it's such an important point. Many of the senators that asked him question didn't even know that Facebook was a free service. And as a result they didn't understand how he was making money. They didn't even know that it's from the advertisers.

So if you don't understand the fundamental business purpose and how they're actually -- their earnings are generated, how are you going to begin to regulate it? And instead of allowing them to get into more and more areas, this can be very dangerous.

BARTIROMO: We'll be watching this hearing. Go ahead -- Congressman. Real quick.

WILLIAMS: Well, I was going to say Dagen -- you asked a good question. How many congress people, I mean, the truth of the matter is, very few. And I don't include myself to be all-knowing. I'm still learning this. We have to ask the questions.

But the problem is sometimes more people, our peers as you know think they know more than they know.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

WILLIAMS: And that's why this hearing is important and maybe those to follow.

BARTIROMO: Well, take that question to your colleagues that Omeed just gave you. You know, why are they getting into this business? Do they want to just track everybody and what they're spending.

Real quick on the push for impeachment, Congressman -- the top American diplomat in Ukraine, William Taylor testified yesterday that President Trump did in fact use aid as an incentive for Ukraine to investigate the Biden family in the 2016 election. Of course then, Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy said that Texas Congressman John Ratcliffe question, quote, "destroyed Taylor's argument".

Do you have any sense of what went down yesterday? And is the public ever going to get a look behind the curtain here in this impeachment inquiry?

WILLIAMS: Well, I don't know. They've been really secret about it. It's not even in the right committee. I know I was in my district last week with the President to open a Louis Vuitton plant in central Texas. And people back home are following it, but it's not important.

But I think it's -- nothing is stuck on the president. It's their only way to think they can win in 2022 -- or 2020.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

WILLIAMS: And it's phony is the bottom line. We've got to get through this. And we've got an election coming up in November and let's let the voters decide.

BARTIROMO: Yes, absolutely. Well, I think it's interesting -- Congressman, that because Taylor had in his opening statement suggestions that there was a quid pro quo, they released his opening statement. Nothing else was released in particular, the questioning by John Ratcliffe which blew a hole in that completely.

MCDOWELL: The House Democrats are essentially auditioning players for what will be a public Christmas pageant -- a holiday pageant of the impeachment proceedings. They're trying to find the best voices to push this message on the American people. So all this is being done in secret. The Republican congressmen aren't even given transcripts of these interviews or depositions.

They have to go in and read the transcript with a Democratic staffer standing next to them.

BARTIROMO: Yes. They've got a minder.

MCDOWELL: Exactly.

BARTIROMO: And that's unprecedented. Never seen --

MCDOWELL: You know what? It's not an impeachment proceeding. They haven't voted on it. It's not --

BARTIROMO: It's a show.

MCDOWELL: -- it's not formal. It's not formal in the way that it was with Clinton and with Richard Nixon. Again, they're not treating this with the seriousness and the severity that it is when you're trying to --

BARTIROMO: But they don't have the vote and they also don't have a story.

MCDOWELL: Really quickly. There was a CNN report that the number of people in favor of impeachment and removal from office has gone up. It's at 50 percent. But if you look at Republicans, the number of people saying yes to that impeachment and removal from office has fallen dramatically. It's only 6 percent of Republicans right now. So support for the President among his base is actually improving.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And I don't see any credibility on the Democrats' side until they focus on the real wrongdoing in 2016. I want to see accountability.

Congressman -- it's good to see you, sir. Thank you.

WILLIAMS: Ok. Good to see you, guys.

BARTIROMO: Congressman Roger Williams joining us there.

Caterpillar, we told you, missed on the third quarter earnings report this morning. It's also lowering its full year guidance.

Joining us right now by phone is Tigress Financial Partners chief investment officer Ivan Feinseth. Ivan -- thanks very much for calling in. Your reaction to the Caterpillar quarter and what it tells us about the global economy.

IVAN FEINSETH, TIGRESS FINANCIAL PARTNERS (via telephone): Well, they do, are experiencing a headwind from slowing global growth, that is mostly trade tariff driven. And when I -- we're moving closer to some type of trade deal with China. I think once that is overcome, I think the shares will snap back.

So I think this is a buying opportunity because global construction demand continues to increase, especially for infrastructure, both in the U.S. and in other countries.

And they do have some other drivers of revenue including their Cloud- connected platform that they are very technology advanced company. And they are buying back stock at a significant rate and the stock does have an over 3 percent dividend yield.

So I still view this weakness as a buying opportunity and we look to some correction once the tariffs are overcome.

BARTIROMO: Well, this is exactly what Omeed said. In fact, had I bought - - when you said it, when the stock was down 6 percent I would have already made money. It's still off of the lows, Omeed -- down 3.9 percent right now.

MALIK: Yes. I couldn't agree more. This, like so many of other names, I love what you said about that acronym about all the ones affected by the trade deal -- you're making a macroeconomic play less than a fundamental one.

BARTIROMO: And is this pretty much priced in -- Ivan? The fact that they took their estimates down? What should we look toward in terms of next move in this stock, do you think? Do you think this is the low that we've seen so far?

SEINFEITH: Well, I think when companies are going to lower expectations, they do become very conservative, to hope that business does pick up and then they can exceed the expectations over the next few quarters.

So I think that they have been conservative throughout this whole tariff issue in the past year-and-a-half. And that has been weighing on the stock for some time. But they are the dominant construction machine producer globally with the most brand equity and I think when stocks are struggling, it's time to -- when stocks struggle, it's time to buy it. And when we see demand pick up I think they will be a significant beneficiary.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll leave it there.

Ivan -- thanks very much for calling in. We appreciate it. Ivan Feinseth joining us there from Tigress.

Coming up, investors are watching Boeing as well, the company's third quarter earnings out in about 30 minutes. We'll have those numbers after this break.

And then Pizza Hut's meatless play -- its the unique sausage pie could trick your taste buds. We're going to check it out.

Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Actress Lori Loughlin and ten other parents facing new charges in the massive college at admissions scandal this morning.

Cheryl Casone on headlines -- Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Yes, Maria.

So prosecutors say that those parents have been indicted on charges of conspiracy to commit federal program bribery. They are accused of attempting to buy off officials at an organization that receives federal funding. The charge carries a maximum sentence of up to five years in prison and a fine of up to $250,000.

Jeff Bezos putting together an all-star team to build a lunar lander for his company Blue Origin. The contractors which include Lockheed Martin and Northrup Grumman and Draper will build a spacecraft to take NASA astronauts to the moon as soon as 2024.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JEFF BEZOS, CEO, AMAZON: This is the only way to get back to the moon fast and this time we're going back to the moon and we're not going to back to the moon to visit. We're going back to the moon to stay.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Well, the system is being built for NASA's Artemis program.

And then finally this. Pizza Hut taking a bite of the plant-based meat fad. They are testing just for today a garden specialty pizza that's topped with "incogmeato" Italian sausage.

So incogmeato is made by Morning Star farms. Kellogg owns that company, by the way. The Pizza-hut tryout is being held tomorrow only at one Pizza Hut location in Phoenix near Scottsdale, if anybody is watching from there.

Pizza Hut is also testing a round pizza box guys, they claim will keep the pizza hot. You all have it on set. Enjoy, as I give you some more details about it. The round box is compostable.

MCDOWELL: So it looks like this.

CASONE: Right.

MCDOWELL: You take the top off.

CASONE: Right.

MCDOWELL: It's got a natural base that your pizza locks in. And it's like -- guess who made it. I didn't mean to interrupt you -- Cheryl.

CASONE: No, that's ok. But about the pizza -- so you all try it or somebody try it because I can't. I'm over here.

BARTIROMO: They made me try it.

(CROSSTALKING)

CASONE: It's not meat. It's plant-based meat.

MCDOWELL: I'm not eating the cheese on it.

CASONE: It's not vegan.

MCDOWELL: No. But the fake -- sorry, the fake sausage is vegan. It's just the --

BARTIROMO: All right. Art -- you took a bite. Tell us.

MALIK: How is it?

HOGAN: It's fantastic. It's really good.

BARTIROMO: Are you kidding me?

HOGAN: And it's really hot, too still which is amazing. But that's part of the -- you see how this box is made?

CASONE: Yes. It's pretty cool, right.

MCDOWELL: So the box was designed alongside Zoom, the company that Meredith Whitney works for us, so she was here telling us about it. This is one of Zoom's products. So it locks in.

BARTIROMO: So Meredith --

MCDOWELL: Yes, exactly. It locks in. It's awesome.

BARTIROMO: I like the lock. That is cool.

MCDOWELL: What are they calling it? The sausage or whatever?

CASONE: Incogmeato.

BARTIROMO: Incogmeato.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Incogmeato.

MCDOWELL: It's delicious.

(CROSSTALKING)

MCDOWELL: It's really -- it's really delicious.

CASONE: If you're near the East Thomas Pizza Hut in Phoenix tomorrow. Go give it a try and e-mail or send us a Twitter message or send some pictures to the show and folks out there let us know what you think.

BARTIROMO: I don't know what I like better, the incogmeato or the round box. I am loving this warm pizza. How come nobody had that idea before -- round pizza boxes?

MCDOWELL: The key to all this -- I've said this before -- the key to all this plant-based the meats, the burgers, the fillings, sausages, does it have the toothiness of the usual, of the real stuff? Does it eat like a burger? Does it eat like crumbled sausage on a pizza? It's yes with this.

BARTIROMO: All right. You said it was delicious.

HOGAN: Very good. Absolutely delicious.

BARTIROMO: Cool.

HOGAN: You guys are getting it right.

BARTIROMO: All right. Thank you -- Cheryl. You're getting the pizza.

CASONE: You bet.

BARTIROMO: Pizza for breakfast.

Coming up, Eli Lilly out with mixed earnings this morning. I'll be speaking with the CEO Dave Ricks when we come right back.

Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Pharmaceutical giant Eli Lilly raising its 2019 profit forecast after reporting better than expected third quarter profits in the last hour. Revenue came in lower than expected however. Take a look at the stock this morning and how it is doing in the premarket right now on the hills of the third quarter earnings from Eli Lilly -- down 2 percent, plus.

Joining us right now in a "First on Fox" interview is Eli Lilly CEO Dave Ricks. Dave -- it's good to have you on the program. Thanks so much for joining us.

DAVE RICKS, CEO, ELI LILLY: Great to be back. Thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: We will really focused on where the growth is coming from at Lilly but first characterize the quarter for us.

RICKS: Yes, overall we had a strong quarter. We grew 3 percent on the top line really driven by 8 percent volume growth which is really our newest products. The company's launched 10 products in the last five years and those are now making up 44 percent of our revenue.

And that's good news because new medicines getting to patients, that's our business strategy that also drives financial success.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Of course. RICKS: We managed cost pretty well and we beat and raised on the bottom line.

BARTIROMO: Well, you've got the recently launched drugs certainly helping to offset some of the generic issues. Is that where the growth comes from in the next six months, in the next year?

RICKS: That's right. You know, that's an important point. As I said, really double digit volume growth driven by our newest products.

We have two headwinds that have showed up in this quarter. One is as you mentions loss of patents on key drugs like Cialis which lost its patent a year ago. We had a 6 percent headwind due to that.

I want to point out, that's an important part of the life cycle of our industry. And now that medicine is very inexpensive for patients who need it.

In addition we had, particularly in the U.S., price deflation -- this has been going on for a few years now. But our U.S. pricing was minus 5 percent, globally minus 4 percent. So those two things together were a drag on growth.

We still grew 3 percent. We do anticipate that drag reducing going forward because both in the case of Cialis which the comparable will get better going into Q4 as well as on the pricing where there is some one-time effects in Q3, we expect improvement on both those headwinds exiting this year into 2020.

BARTIROMO: And real quick on the cancer drug, the pancreatic cancer drug, not meeting the primary end point in the overall survival. What can you tell us about that in terms of your cancer drugs and this pancreatic one that was a disappointment. Do you see that coming back in terms of the next year for another review?

RICKS: So yes -- thank you for the question. You're talking about a drug called pegilodecakin (ph) which we purchased a year and-a-half ago. It's being studied in three important studies.

The pancreatic cancer study was disappointing, not that surprising unfortunately, because pancreatic cancer has really proven to be one of the most difficult settings and difficult condition for patients.

But we're also studying it in two forms of lung cancer on top of other immuno-oncology therapies. Those readouts are coming toward the end of this this year, early next year. We're excited to see those readouts with this very novel mechanism that really seeks to partner with other immuno- oncology therapies to improve patients' lives.

We also, I would point out -- we had three other important readouts in the quarter in oncology. One in breast cancer with Verzenio which showed an overall survival benefit over nine months for the first time. That's an important benefit for patients.

And in two readouts on a drug we acquired earlier this year called selpercatinib (ph) Loxo 292, the acquisition of Loxo Oncology which showed enormous benefit really in lung cancer as well as in thyroid cancer. So a successful quarter for oncology overall. Of course, disappointing news on the pancreatic study.

BARTIROMO: Well, I'm glad you said that because, you know, the fight against cancer continues every day. You guys have had some real innovative drugs in terms of oncology.

Would you -- is it fair to say that now with the acquisition you just mentioned, with the patents sort of hopefully in the rear view mirror, are you back toward a growth trajectory in terms of the pipeline and what's ahead for the coming five years? Or do you still have to deal with these patent expirations over the near term?

RICKS: Well, that's a key thing about our company is I think we have relatively few patent expiries both in this year but going forward, versus the rest of the industry. We do project strong growth going forward. In fact, between 2016 and 2020, we had projected average of 7 percent growth and we aim to hit that as we set guidance later this year, going into 2020.

And I think we have a bright future, really driven by the newest medicines and a relative lack of patent exposure in our portfolio. And of course, that's great news for patients, new medicines for serious conditions. We were talking about cancer just now but also diabetes, auto autoimmune conditions which are quite prevalent and pain which is an emerging area for us, non-opioid pain medicines really to help people with the most common condition that people have when they go to the doctor which is something hurts and we know all the problems with opioids. Lilly is inventing new ways to treat pain that don't have those negative properties.

BARTIROMO: And Dave -- real quick. Is that an organic growth story or do you see an opportunity for further acquisitions in terms of filling some of those holes?

RICKS: It's both. Of course, we need a strong team of scientists. We have a great team of scientists here, discovering new medicines every day and attempting to get those to patients. But we complement that with partnerships and acquisitions, with biotech and other major pharma.

That's how our industry works. And we need to be active in all those areas but really focused on the diseases we know how to add value --

(CROSSTALKING)

BARTIROMO: Dave -- great to have you on the program this morning. Thanks so much.

RICKS: Thanks for having me. Thank you -- Maria.

BARTIROMO: Dave Ricks joining us there, CEO of Eli Lilly.

We are awaiting Boeing earnings amid questions of the 737 Max. Just yesterday the aerospace company announced that it is replacing the head of its commercial airplanes division.

Joining us right now is Blue Line Capital President, Bill Baruch and Stifel Airlines Analyst, Joseph DeNardi. Great to see you gentleman. Thanks very much for joining us as we await the Boeing earnings; they are coming out any second here.

Bill, your expectations in terms of what drove the quarter?

BILL BARUCH, PRESIDENT, BLUE LINE CAPITAL: I want to see how this thing responds on a price action basis. Now, they -- yesterday they talked about significant progress on the 737. Do they follow through? Do we see that come back on the quarter four? On top of that, do they announce any guidance? People overall just want to hear the guidance, even if it is bad. That could actually be a positive.

So lastly, the $5.6 million hit in July they announced, is it worse than that? Obviously if they announce the worse we could see the stock react more poorly.

BARTIROMO: Yes, Joseph, it looks like the numbers are amiss on the earnings line. The 737 obviously has been the big issue. When you look at the earnings and the revenue over the near term, how big of an issue is the 737 going to be and for how much longer?

JOSEPH DENARDI, AIRLINES ANALYST, STIFEL: Yes, I think most U.S. airlines seem to assume that it's going to -- you know, be returned to service early next year. Obviously, that's several months later than they thought it was going to be returned a few months ago and so I think their view on when it comes back is just based on kind of their best guess at this point.

And so, yes, I think they're hoping it comes back as soon as Boeing's able to get it back in the air.

BARTIROMO: Well, the costs are obviously increasing for this company. That's also showing up in this quarter. Let's get to Jackie DeAngelis with the -- with the numbers on earnings and revenue which is a miss and the stock is trading down, Jackie.

JACKIE DEANGELIS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK FINANCIAL CORRESPONDENT: It is a miss, Maria. And you can see the EPS, $1.45 adjusted. The expectation was $2.09. The revenue came in slightly higher at $19.98 billion, expectation there of $19.67 billion.

But as you mentioned, the 737 Max jet is really what's in focus this quarter. We actually have a quote from the CEO, saying our top priority remains the safe return to service of the 737 Max. And we're making steady progress there. That was the CEO, Dennis Muilenburg.

He also continues to say we've also taken action to further sharpen our company's focus on product and services safety. Maria, for now I'll send it back to you.

BARTIROMO: I'll tell you one thing, while you were talking, Jackie, we're seeing a real comeback in the stock. Right after the news were -- was released, you saw a decline of better than two percent, and it is off of the lows. Jackie DeAngelis, thank you. Omeed.

MALIK: Yes, so it's all well and good for the company to say that they think the 737 issue is behind them or it's getting to the finish line. I want to ask our guests about the regulatory issues, though, as well. Because it's really going to be ultimately up to the regulators. So how about the disconnect between the FAA here in the United States versus their equivalent in Europe and the disconnect that might occur between there as far as where these planes can actually fly. Do you guys have a thought on that?

BARTIROMO: What do you think, Bill?

BARUCH: Well, overall actually this could take weeks. I mean, it'd be -- it would be a big achievement to see this fly again in quarter four. You're probably looking at the quarter -- you know, and the first quarter of next year at best. And that's what the stock is responding to now.

What really matters, I look at this price action and there's a big support area, 320, and then a shelf below at $3.00. I always say, what are the best technical moves is a fundamental rejection. If we're rejecting lower prices on poor fundamentals right now and the market moves higher, that in it of itself is taking some of the sellers or most of the sellers are out of the market.

BARTIROMO: Yes, and then there's the impact on the airlines, Joe, right? I mean, the 737 Max affect has obviously impacted airlines like Southwest and JetBlue. Your reaction to that?

DENARDI: Well, in the -- in the airline industry, any constraint on capacity is good. And so, you know, in general what that's meant this year is have been better pricing trends and less capacity growth and so I think what airline investors are worried about next year is how much supply is going to come back online when the Max comes back in. To the extent that the -- that the return to service gets delayed, that's not necessarily a bad thing for airlines.

Our view is that Southwest may look at that as kind of an unacceptable risk for them if they're not able to grow and execute their strategy, they may have to look to diversify their fleet away from the Max in order to grow and not lose share.

And so I think what Southwest is probably most keyed in on at this point is Boeing's confidence that they'll be able to get production rates back to where they thought they would be and deliver to Southwest the 40 to 50 Maxes a year that they're going to need the next few years to grow and execute their strategy.

HOGAN: Joe, you bring up a really good point in terms of the diversity that Southwest has -- that has all of a sudden, you know, been sort of pointed out for not having and using all the Boeing product and none of the Airbus product where other airlines have some sort of combination of both.

But at the end of the day, I think what you really bring up is the fact that we have a duopoly here. And if that's the case and we think the 737 Max is going to get back up into production and up in the air at some point in 2020, how much of that eventuality do you think is priced in right now, what multiple is Boeing trading at and how much will the eventual success of the 737 getting back in the air at some point, let's call it the first half of next year is in there, and how risk -- how derisked does the stock look today?

DENARDI: Yes, I think -- I think ultimately it comes back to -- yes, I'm sorry. Go ahead.

BARUCH: Go ahead -- go ahead. Sorry.

BARTIROMO: Bill, you take it. Go ahead, Bill.

DENARDI: Ultimately it comes back to --

BARUCH: You know, I'm looking at 20 times multiple. I mean, you can see if someone is -- that's where they're seeing valuing down here and ultimately, again, 20 times multiple, so you can see something come back in online the first half of next year and buyers down here are going to see that progress later in the next year.

BARTIROMO: All right, go ahead, Joe. Sorry about that. Yes, I just do -- I know you follow the airlines, Joe. And wanted to make sure that you were on track with where you were following. But please weigh in.

DENARDI: No, I think ultimately it comes back to Boeing's ability to get rates back to where they thought they would be. That's ultimately I think what investors are most concerned about and I think as it relates to airlines, you know, that's going to have a pretty meaningful impact on supply growth in the U.S.

Southwest represents, you know, call it 20 percent of domestic capacity, 10 percent of their own capacity, roughly should be on the Max right now. And so how quickly they're able to get those aircraft back into service has a pretty big impact on supply trends.

MCDOWELL: But what -- this is Dagen McDowell, Joe. Would Southwest bet on Airbus at a time when this administration is in a trade fight? I'm not talking about China, but that $7.5 billion award from the World Trade Organization over this long-running fight over the subsidies to Airbus. Would Southwest really bet on a com -- in that duopoly that competitor overseas that could be in the middle of a fight with the president?

DENARDI: That's a really good point. I think that's probably a consideration for Southwest.

I mean, look, at the end of the day, Southwest would prefer to not do anything. They would prefer to remain as a single fleet type and continue to do what they've been doing. It's resulted in them being the most successful airline in the industry. The point that we're trying to make is if they look a few years down the road -- they've expressed frustration that this year their supply is down year over year, while the rest of the industry is up four to five percent. That means that they are giving customers to other airlines. And they've accepted that to this point.

But if they lose confidence in Boeing's ability to give them the Maxes that they need to grow and do what they want to do, then they don't have many options other than either to try and convince Airbus to give them delivery slots which probably don't exist, or to do something inorganic and there aren't many airlines in the U.S. that the DOJ would allow Southwest to buy, I think. JetBlue would be one of them.

And so I think Southwest has to balance this, the risks that you brought up with the risk that maybe their capacity is constrained for a prolonged period of time when capacity at their competitors is not.

BARTIROMO: Is anybody surprised that this stock is sort of pushing to go positive right now? Caterpillar has given up -- I'm sorry, Boeing has given up much of the losses that we saw earlier and, Bill, they're sticking with this expectation that the 737 Max up, it just went positive, gets back in the air in the fourth quarter. Are you buying that? And look at the stock now, up on the session; it's up a quarter percent.

BARUCH: Well, they laid that groundwork yesterday. And really my thesis here was seeing that they wanted to get ahead of poor earnings and they did get ahead of what was overall seem poor earnings. But they're sticking with the fact that you're going to see this come back on the quarter and next this quarter.

So, if they follow through, yes, there's a -- there's a lot higher the stock can go, there's a lot of support down here. But remember, Friday was a very poor day for this stock. And what we're running into is that price action from Friday.

So it has a -- has a tall task to start recovering all of that. You don't really want to change this price action. You're going to see a lot of gyrations back and forth. And again, this is one number, but -- and if I understand correctly, there still is no true guidance out there. And if there's no true guidance out there, you're still going to see a lot of expectations waffle around.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I mean, they're talk -- they're talking about costs going up and they're talking about the 737 returning to the air in the fourth quarter but we don't see a guidance for the next year, that's true. Bill Baruch, Joseph DeNardi, good to see you both gentleman. Thank you so much.

DENARDI: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: We'll keep watching the story. And as you know, Caterpillar was a miss; that stock is down. But Boeing is now up. We'll see what that means for the markets. We're still expecting a 90 point selloff at the start of trading this morning for the Dow Industrials.

Coming up, we are bracing for the holidays, I'll be speaking with the CEO of UPS David Abney on how his company is prepping for the peak shipping season.

And then Lexus plugged in the automaker unveils its first ever electric vehicle. The photos and when you can power up, next up.

CASONE: Welcome back to MORNINGS WITH MARIA. I'm Cheryl Casone with some headlines for you.

Chipotle out with sizzling earnings after the bell. But it is not all good news. Shares initially climbed after its latest results came in better than expected but the stock is losing ground this morning, down almost a little more than 1-1/2 percent.

Online sales soared 88 percent during the quarter but delivery costs also rose. That said; Chipotle is up more than 90 percent so far this year.

Meantime, Snap is trading higher in the premarket, stock up almost two percent; the parent of Snapchat reported a narrow than expected loss and revenue which beat the streets estimate. The number of active users increased by seven million. That did top expectations from analysts.

Well, Facebook is investing $1 billion to tackle the affordable housing crisis in California. Company says it's going to build 20,000 housing units over the next 10 years. Experts say the Bay Area economy has created one home for every 10 new jobs over the past decade. A lot of those are high paying jobs. That has caused home prices to skyrocket.

Facebook has been blamed for helping create this crisis, bringing tens of thousands of those higher paid workers into the Bay Area.

Lexus is plugging into the future. The automaker says it's going to unveil its first electric vehicle next month. And it's already showing off a concept car, the LF-30, there it is. It features a lot of futuristic tech like gesture control and artificial intelligence to adjust all the settings on the car and of course, yes, it drives itself.

All right, we've got a lot more coming up this morning. Holiday shipping almost here. Maria going to be speaking with UPS CEO David Abney coming up next on prepping for the peak season as customers hit that online store and all that shopping starts. We'll be right back.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. The holiday shopping season already heating up, meaning holiday shipping season is on deck as well. A lot of that shipping falling to UPS. The company maintains its relationship with Amazon after it dumped FedEx, helping growth.

Joining me right now is the CEO of UPS, David Abney. David, it's great to have you. Thank you so much for joining us.

DAVID ABNEY, CEO, UPS: Nice to be here, Maria.

BARTIROMO: You just characterized your quarter as the best quarter in the company's history.

ABNEY: It absolutely was.

BARTIROMO: Tell us about it.

ABNEY: And it was balanced across all three sectors which is very important to us. I think the sector that's gotten the most attention is the U.S. domestic business, very, very strong. For this quarter compared to last year at the same time, we reduced our unit cost 2-1/2 percent which is something that I don't remember seeing before. And that resulted in the operating profit for the U.S. business grew 26 percent, so just an excellent quarter.

BARTIROMO: How did you -- how were you able to get a handle on costs so well, and decline those?

ABNEY: It really is the result of a lot of work that we've done. It's our strategies. It's our strategic imperatives that we've focused on. It is the investments that we have made in automating our buildings and optimizing our routes. So we're really getting the payback from those investments. And then at the end, its execution and our people just did an excellent job executing.

BARTIROMO: You are headed into now one of the most important times of the year, obviously. Are you expecting a surge in volumes around the holidays and what's your expectation for growth around that?

ABNEY: We do believe it's going to be a busy holiday season. Four less workdays between Thanksgiving and Christmas this year which just means that there's less days for a lot of the promotions that start right around Thanksgiving.

So we have built up, we have added this year five million additional square feet in buildings. That's 400,000 packages an hour that we can run over last year. And we've added 11 aircraft which is good, because with the change from second day to next day, we needed the additional lift. So we have it.

BARTIROMO: Going into the quarter, with the resignation of your COO, can you give us the impact there and what you're expecting?

ABNEY: Yes, I think what you have to keep in mind; Jim has been with us 35 years. So it was definitely a retirement and well-deserved, did an excellent job. He's going to work through us through peak. We have a solid bench of people too. So while we're going to miss Jim, obviously this organization keeps going and we have good people in the wing.

BARTIROMO: So David, the last time we spoke we were sort of right smack in the middle of this trade fight, whether it's China, the uncertainty over USMCA. What has that done in terms of your market expectations and where we are with regard to this trade impacting overall growth, overall manufacturing?

ABNEY: There's been bright spots since we talked and then there's things that are still ongoing. So it's -- you know, I think it has more of an effect of customers looking to change their trade patterns. And so we have to look at how we move our assets around to adjust to those trade patterns.

A good example is our 747-8, our biggest aircraft. We were had them planned to go to China to the U.S. since the U.S. lane has reduced due to the trade war, we've actually moved one of those planes, China to Europe. And it's those kinds of things we do.

USMCA, we think is a bright spot. We think that Lighthizer's done a great job of getting bipartisan support, really believe that will be ratified.

China to U.S., there's -- the latest talks seem to be going in the right directions, so we're hopeful there.

And then with Brexit, we're just having to watch. It's kind of a day-to- day news breaker right now. But we'll see.

BARTIROMO: Yes, we're all waiting to see what happens there. Your sense of the B2B business right now which is so important for UPS, the small and mid-cap businesses, how would you characterize things?

ABNEY: That is our primary focus is to lean in and to make sure that we take care of the small and mid-size businesses. What they want is one thing, really. And that is to be able to compete from a logistics standpoint with the big e-tailors and retailers.

So we just introduced a digital access program and partnership with Shopify and with Stuffs.com and others. What that does is it gives access to their 1.5 million small businesses into our network.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

ABNEY: And so it's really it's a significant move and that is our focus is to help small and mid-size businesses compete.

BARTIROMO: And I assume that would mean you're also affecting costs pretty efficiently as well with this -- with your new technology.

ABNEY: We are. And that technology allows us to connect to these programs. B2B is going to be multiple packages per stop and that's what really makes a difference.

And the fact that we're automating our buildings and optimizing our routes, all of that helps B2B. And it's one of the reasons that we had such a good quarter.

BARTIROMO: Tell us after -- about the drone business. UPS expanding its Flight Forward drone program after becoming the first company to gain FAA approval to transport medical supplies by drone. Really an interesting development.

ABNEY: Yes, we put a stake in the ground that we were going to be the first to get this certification from the FAA and we've worked real hard to do that.

Then we put a stake that we were going to be the first to scale it and because a lot of people may have wondered, could UPS take the market lead here, and we absolutely showed that we did. We announced partnerships with AmerisourceBergen with Kaiser Permanente and with CVS, so all three just really outstanding companies that we will be progressing our drone usage. And then we will go outside healthcare pretty quickly too.

BARTIROMO: That is amazing.

ABNEY: But the initial focus is healthcare.

BARTIROMO: So you are approved to move supplies at WakeMed in Raleigh North Carolina and University Of Utah Health in Salt Lake City. Is that the goal to get more and more of those kinds of customers and partnerships to move these medical supplies?

ABNEY: Yes, that's the initial phase is to -- any of these campus type environments, we chose healthcare but it could be other campus type environments.

But the CVS, what makes it so interesting, it's the first retail partnership we have done and we're going to start testing quickly about actually taking shipments such as pharmaceuticals from a local CVS store and delivering it to homes. So --

BARTIROMO: That's such a convenience.

ABNEY: It will be. And if it's something that you need very quickly, I mean, there's no faster delivery than drone deliveries. So we think it plays an important role.

BARTIROMO: All right, so look ahead, David, to the next year or three. Where does the growth come from at UPS?

ABNEY: International still would be big growth area for us. Europe by the way, as we're continuing to gain market share, we're doing very well there.

BARTIROMO: Are you seeing any growth in Europe?

ABNEY: Yes, we are. And we're kind of against the mode. And so that's going well for us.

BARTIROMO: All right, David, it's great to have you.

ABNEY: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. David Abney, UPS. We'll be right back.

urn:contentItem:5TY6-7TR1-JC0C-J4YS-00000-00Questions to Google CEO hint at Dems' agenda Misinformation, privacy top list; Pichai denies political bias in search programming2018-12-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:20:02ZLexisNexisAPg. 012Questions to Google CEO hint at Dems' agenda Misinformation, privacy top list; Pichai denies political bias in search programmingMarcy Gordon and Barbara Ortutay Associated Press

WASHINGTON - Google CEO Sundar Pichai - and other tech executives who may be watching - got hints Tuesday of what issues they can expect to face as Democrats take control of the House in three weeks.

While Republicans on the House Judiciary Committee grilled Pichai on what they perceive as bias against conservatives, top committee Democrat Jerrold Nadler said lawmakers should instead examine issues such as the spread of misinformation online and Russians' efforts to influence U.S. elections online.

The issue of user privacy also came up over and over. Looming over the tech industry is the possibility of government regulation intended to protect people's data and a deeper look into whether gigantic companies like Google, Amazon and Facebook need to be broken up.

Pichai's first appearance ever before Congress comes after he angered members of a Senate panel in September by declining their invitation to testify about election manipulation. Pichai's no-show at that hearing was marked by an empty chair for Google alongside the Facebook and Twitter executives who did appear. Lawmakers declined Google's offer to send lower-level executives.

Pichai went to Washington later in September to mend fences, meeting with some two dozen Republicans and indicating he also planned to meet with Democrats. He took part in last week's White House meeting with other tech executives on getting government and businesses working more closely on accelerating emerging technologies such as artificial intelligence.

Pichai reiterated Google's position that it has no plans "right now" to re-enter China with a search engine generating censored results to comply with the demands of that country's Communist government. If that changes, Pichai promised to be "fully transparent" about the move. Pichai has said that he wants Google to be in China serving Chinese users.

The CEO also insisted that Google's search engine is not biased against any political viewpoint.

President Donald Trump has accused Google of rigging search results to suppress conservative viewpoints and highlight coverage from media that he says distribute "fake news." The company has denied any such bias, and while the question has dogged tech companies for years, there's no evidence of an anti-conservative or any other political tilt.

Nadler called the notion of bias a "delusion" and a "right-wing conspiracy theory." The New York Democrat said Tuesday's hearing was the committee's fourth to address the topic - and he suggested he'd move on to other topics as Democrats take control.

House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy, R-Calif., kicked off the hearing by noting a "widening gap of distrust" between tech companies and the American people.

Asked for yes-or-no answers on what information the company collects, Pichai demurred and attempted to convey that things are more complicated, with varying degrees of success.

Momentum is building in Congress for legislation to put stricter limits and privacy protections around the big tech companies' collection of data.

Rep. Ted Poe, R-Texas, tried to pin down Pichai concretely on privacy. "I've got an iPhone," Poe said, waving his device. "Can Google track me when I move?" If he moved to the left toward his Democratic colleagues on the panel, would Google know?

"Not by default," Pichai answered. Poe demanded a yes or no answer, but Pichai indicated it was complicated.

Trump and some lawmakers have raised the possibility of asking regulators to investigate whether Google - which handles nearly two of every three online searches in the U.S. - has abused its clout as a major gateway to the internet to stifle competition.

Responding to a question about Google's search dominance, Pichai pointed to Amazon's dominance in online shopping.

Pichai, a former engineer, took the helm of Google in 2015 in a major restructuring that made Google a division of conglomerate Alphabet Inc. - whose businesses include Waymo, a self-driving technology development company.

Bolstering the dominance of its search engine, Google's Android operating system runs most of the world's smartphones, and its other services - including Gmail, YouTube, online ads and the Chrome web browser - are widely used.

urn:contentItem:5R65-M891-DY60-K1NB-00000-00Quest: Is this Trump's economy?2017-12-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:20:02ZLexisNexisINVESTINGQuest: Is this Trump's economy?Richard Quest

Quest's Profitable Moment

As the U.S. economy picks up speed, with low unemployment and rising consumer confidence, some of you have written to me criticizing that we are not giving enough credit to President Trump for this economic nirvana.

There is a good reason: According to most private economists, this is not yet Donald Trump's economy. The landscape we are currently enjoying is the handiwork of Janet Yellen's Federal Reserve and Barack Obama's White House.

Those who write to me don't agree. Their argument is that companies are bringing back investment, creating new jobs and there is new confidence because of the prospects of lower taxes, massive deregulation and stronger trade protections for American companies. In other words, President Trump has created this environment and he deserves the credit for its benefits.

I can see the merit of this argument. Unfortunately, most private sector economists, like Professor Ken Rogoff at Harvard, a former chief economist at the IMF, don't agree with it. Time and again, these economists say, yes, Trump has had an effect, but it's too soon to give him full credit.

The debate will continue. I won't take sides. Instead, we will just bring you both arguments, allowing you to make up your own mind. Anytime you want to write to me, my email address is below.

And the Mouse ran away with the Fox

Disney's purchase of the movie studio assets of 21st Century Fox makes Disney a more formidable player in Hollywood.

It gives Disney the rights to Marvel characters such as the X-Men that Fox owned. It will boost the chances of success for the Disney and Fox-backed Hulu and Disney's own streaming service that it plans to launch to fight Netflix.

But Disney may inherit a mess in Europe as Fox tries to buy Sky. The deal may also complicate the legacy of Fox CEO Rupert Murdoch while bolstering the reputation of Disney CEO Bob Iger.

Prophetically enough, Fox's "The Simpsons" predicted a deal in 1998.

-- Paul R. La Monica

Fed hikes rates as Yellen set to pass baton

In a move that surprised nobody, the Federal Reserve raised interest rates for the third time this year Wednesday.

It's a sign of a healthy economy, which was further confirmed Thursday after the government reported a drop in the number of people filing for unemployment claims and strong retail sales for November.

Still, outgoing Fed chair Janet Yellen warned that President Trump's tax plan will boost the deficit and could make it tougher for her planned successor Jerome Powell to deal with future crises.

Yellen also urged people to be careful when buying bitcoin, which she referred to as "a highly speculative asset."

-- Paul R. La Monica

Bitcoin: Is North Korea making a fortune?

Bitcoin mania continues to heat up.

In just the past week, bitcoin futures launched and regulators warned investors to be wary. Kim Jong Un could be making a fortune on the boom because North Korea has recently been "mining" bitcoin, stealing it and demanding it as ransom payment.

Bitcoin has really taken off in South Korea, where trading has gone mainstream.

One threat to bitcoin -- something newer that could replace it. With that in mind, keep an eye on litecoin, the smaller cryptocurrency that has surged by more than bitcoin over the past month.

-- Matt Egan

Britain won't let Big Tech off the hook

A top U.K. ethics panel said Wednesday that Facebook, Twitter and Google should take "more responsibility" for illegal content on their platforms. The Committee on Standards in Public Life, which advises Prime Minister Theresa May, said the situation calls for new legislation.

Meanwhile, the head of a parliamentary committee investigating the role of fake news and online misinformation in the U.K. said Wednesday that Facebook needed to look harder for Russian meddling before the Brexit vote. Facebook said a Russian troll farm that spent $100,000 in the U.S. had spent only $0.97 in Britain.

-- Julia Horowitz

Quick takes

The fight for the future of the internet: What the end of net neutrality means

Get the popcorn ready! Saudi Arabia ends 35-year ban on movie theaters

Trade tensions: Canada deals blow to Boeing by scrapping $5B fighter jet deal

For nearly half of all American households, the rent is still too damn high

Exxon surrenders on major climate change transparency fight with investors

Attention meat lovers: Meat could be taxed in a bid to stop global warming

What's next

Earnings time: A few big names report quarterly earnings next week. FedEx will release results on Tuesday, along with General Mills on Wednesday and Nike on Thursday.

Bitcoin futures: Last Sunday, bitcoin futures started trading on the CBOE. CME Group will follow suit this coming Monday. It's all part of the bitcoin craze, which shows no signs of abating.
